1.text:
It takes around two hours to boil an ostrich
egg.

10.text:
There are castles for sale in France that
are cheaper than two bedroom apartments in

15.text:
Australia.
Chopping wood increases testosterone production

19.text:
by 46.8%, which is 17% higher than most competitive
sports.

25.text:
In the early 1900s a woman named Dorothy Eady
from London made substantial contributions

31.text:
to Egyptology after she hit her head as a
toddler and claimed to have unlocked a past

37.text:
life as a priestess in Ancient Egypt.
Ground up red squirrel testicles injected

42.text:
into the bloodstream were once considered
to be the secret to eternal youth by Dr. Horace

48.text:
Emmett. One year after he announced this at
a Cambridge lecture, touting his newfound

53.text:
virility as proof, he died of a cerebral haemorrhage.
The longest place name in the world is a hill

60.text:
in New Zealand called this: Taumatawhakatangihangakoauauotamateaturipukakapikimaungahoronukupoka-wenuakitanatahu.
Walt Disney used many dummy corporations to

67.text:
purchase the massive amounts of land needed
for Disney World. But his plan was publicised

72.text:
and whilst his first acres were purchased
for around $80, the last ones were over $80,000

77.text:
each.
In Germany there are fake bus stops outside

81.text:
many nursing homes to prevent senior citizens
with Alzheimers from wandering off.

87.text:
There is a city called Rome on every continent.
Slugs have four noses.

93.text:
If two pieces of metal with a similar composition,
such as two pieces of copper, touch in space

99.text:
they instantly become one. This process is
known as cold welding.

104.text:
According to a study performed by Pew Research
in 2010, atheists knew more in general about

111.text:
different religions than religious people
did. With Jews coming in a close second and

117.text:
Mormons in third place.
The male scorpion fly gets other males to

121.text:
bring him food by imitating a female fly.
A crocodile cannot stick out its tongue.

129.text:
One of the early names for Iceland was Snowland,
another was Butterland.

134.text:
In March 2014, an unnamed British sniper in
Afghanistan killed six insurgents with a single

141.text:
bullet. He hit the target from 850 metres
away, which was a trigger switch of a suicide

148.text:
bomber, whose device then exploded. Thereby
preventing a major attack by the Taliban.
